citation.article-title: Description of Bartonella clarridgeiae sp. nov. isolated from the cat of a patient with Bartonella henselae septicemia.
citation.source: Medical Microbiology Letters : an international journal for rapid communications on all aspects of medical and clinical microbiology

p.s: Description of Bartonella clarridgeiae sp. nov.
Bartonella clarridgeiae (The name is to honour the American microbiologist Jill E. Clarridge, III who first isolated the organism)

By gram-stain the Houston-2 cat strain fits the description of the genus Bartollella in being small (about 0.5 x 1.2 μ) pleomorphic gram-negative coccobacilli or slightly curved rods similar in size to B. quintana and B. henselae but somewhat smaller than B. elizabethae and B. vinsonii.

When grown at 35°C with added humidity and CO2, colonies form slowly (visible at 5 days) on initial isolation; on subculture the colonies are about 0.5 mm at 10 days and appear white, raised, indurant (cauliflower-like) and cohesive.
Growth of the Houston-2 cat strain is supported on many blood containing media such as brain heart infusion (BBL) or trypticase soy agar (BEL) with 5 to 10% sheep blood.
After subculture, the Houston-2 cat strain colonies can become smooth and round.
Compared to the Houston-2 cat strain, B. elizabethae and B. vinsonii strains grew faster and formed larger colonies while B. henselae and B. quintana grew slower and formed smaller colonies.
Cells of the Houston-2 cat strain possess flagella which are polar and number about 3 per bacteria (Fig. 1).
With the exception of B. bacilliformis, all other Bartonella spp. lack flagella (1, 3).
The Houston-2 cat strain gave negative reactions for catalase, urease, esculin hydrolysis, nitrate reduction, oxidase and carbohydrate utilization.

By measuring preformed enzymes (RapID Ana II) the strain was found to be biochemically inert except for the production of peptidases; the profile number was 000671 indicating negative reactions to carbohydrates and positive reactions for the cleavage of leucyl-glycine, glycine, proline, phenylalanine, arginine, and serine.
The determined 165 rRNA gene sequence of the Houston-2 cat strain consisted of 1466 nucleotides.
Comparative sequence searches of EMBL and GenBank data libraries showed Bartonella to be the closest genealogical relatives of the Houstoncat strain.
The 165 rRNA gene sequence of the cat strain showed 97.4 to 98.5% similarity with the sequences of other Bartonella spp. (1,2).
Although this degree of relatedness is high, it is lower than the levels of similarities exhibited between several other genotypically distinct (as shown by DNA-DNA pairing) Bartonella spp.
A tree depicting the phylogenetic position of the Houston-2 strain amongst the Bartonellaceae and relatives is shown in Fig 2.

Consistent with pairwise sequence values (Table 1), the treeing analysis showed the cat strain to be genealogically distinct and having no particularly close genotypic affinity with any other recognized Bartonella spp.
Although the cat strain clustered near the periphery of Bartonella, its inclusion does not alter the monophyletic nature of the genus.
It is evident from the phylogenetic analysis that the Houston-2 strain from the cat of a patient with B. henselae septicemia (3) represented a new subline within the genus Bartonella.

Although a precise correlation between percent 165 rRNA sequence relatedness and speciation is not possible, the levels of sequence divergence (approx. 1.5 to 2.6%) between the Houston-2 cat strain and other Bartonella spp. are substantially higher than observed divergence values between other Bartonella spp. known to be genotypically distinct using DNA-DNA pairing (1).
These considerations together with the distinct line formed by the Houston-2 strain within the Bartonella tree clearly indicate this organism constitutes a new species.

It is pertinent to note that the Houston-2 strain is also readily distinguished from other Bartonella species by citrate synthase gene sequence homology and in possessing a unique REP-peR pattern (3).
Within the Bartonellaceae, these two genetic approaches are known to distinguish between all described species.

The two Bartonella spp. which possess flagella (viz: B. bacilliformis, Houston2 cat strain) may be separated by RapID AnaII results, rate of growth, colony type and most definitely by CFA composition analysis (3).
Other species with RapID Ana code 000671 do not have 'flagella and usually grow more slowly.

Therefore based on the phenotypic distinctiveness of the organism and genotypic criteria we consider the Houston-2 cat strain to represent a new species, for which the name Bartonella clarridgeiae sp. nov. is proposed.
The description of Bartonella clarridgeiae is as described above and the type strain is Houston-2 cat (ATCC 51734).
The determined 16S rRNA gene sequence of Bartonella clarridgeiae strain Houston-2 car has been deposited in EMBL data library under accession number X89208.
